profileText: A Representative and a Senator from New Hampshire; born in Roxbury, Mass., July 22, 1880; attended the public schools and Roxbury (Mass.) Latin School; moved to Temple, N.H., in 1903 and engaged in the raising of poultry; also engaged in insurance, agriculture, banking, and manufacturing; member, State house of representatives 1915-1916, 1919-1920, 1923-1924, serving as speaker 1919-1920; member, State senate, serving as president 1925-1926; Governor of New Hampshire 1929-1930; trustee of Colby Junior College, New London, N.H.; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-third, Seventy-fourth, and Seventy-fifth Congresses (March 4, 1933-January 3, 1939); was not a candidate for renomination in 1938; elected to the United States Senate in 1938; reelected in 1944 and again in 1950 and served from January 3, 1939, until his death; chairman, Committee on Banking and Currency (Eightieth Congress), Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce (Eighty-third Congress); United States adviser, UNESCO Conference in Paris 1952; member of the United States delegation to the International Monetary Conference held in Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1944; died of coronary thrombosis in the naval hospital at Bethesda, Md., July 24, 1953; interment in Miller Cemetery, Temple, N.H.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: U.S. Congress. Memorial Services Held in the House of Representatives and Senate of the United States, Together with Remarks Presented in Eulogy of Charles William Tobey, Late a Senator from New Hampshire. 83d Cong., 2d sess., 1954. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1954.

researchRecord.name: 1933-1953. 175 feet. Political correspondence, speeches, press releases, printed matter, scrapbooks of newspaper clippings, photographs, and memorabilia related to his political career, especially during World War II and the postwar period, when he served on Banking and Currency Committee, Committee on Interstate Commerce, Select Committee on Small Business, Foreign Relations Committee, Kefauver Crime Committee, and as a delegate to International Monetary Conference at Bretton Woods, NH. Includes material on devaluation of the dollar, Office of Price Administration, Lendlease and Neutrality Acts, revision of Taft-Hartley legislation, proposed appointment of Mark Clark as U.S. ambassador to the Vatican, and the Dies and McCarthy committee activities. Finding aid. Restricted.
Correspondence in Robert Perkins Bass papers, 1849-1954; and Elba Chase Nelson papers, 1908-1967.
Correspondence in George Henry Duncan papers, 1938-1951; and campaign material of his opponent in Foster Waterman Stearns papers, 1943-1944.
